comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: During the 1890 maritime dispute, the building at 34-40 Harrington St was briefly used by the NSW Labour Defence Committee as a barracks for non-unionists (as a place to feed and house them in an attempt to keep them on side) Here's a September 1890 Sydney Mail pic and article (see article on previous pages) - news.google.com/newspapers?id=g_1UAAAAIBAJ&sjid=RJMDA... and a SMH report - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13783177 I gather 34-40 has been known as Evans Stores...but I can't yet find any 19th century reference to it by that name...I'm still searching for contemporary newspaper reports which might refer to its construction...(one present day source has 1887, another has 1890)...the building has no doubt had an interesting life...digitised newspaper hits indicate Ah Sing had a grocery store there in 1913...a soup kitchen was established there in 1919...there's a bit of interesting stuff on 34-40 and the terraces next door here if you want to download 13MB - www.baseline.nsw.gov.au/hpr/documents/public/241/referenc...

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] I think you've got the street numbers confused here. I have just identified the building in the distance as Dyers' Buildings, 30/32 Harrington Street - www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons/8078585109/ If you look at The Rocks - resumption plan, 1901 on Archives Investigator, it shows this intersection as the beginning of Harrington Street, the buildings on the left being no. 2, 4, 6 and the building you've marked as 34-40 being no. 10-12. The terraces are nos. 14-24. 34-40 are the terraces shown here at the other end of the street near Globe Street - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/4625663728/]

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Yes I now realise I've had my wires crossed here (!)...I've removed my erroneous large notes so you can enlarge your correct small ones...I've just now skimmed thru... www.baseline.nsw.gov.au/hpr/documents/public/241/referenc... ...paying a bit more attention this time...I notice on p. 37 it mentions that Harrington St was renumbered in 1924...and that prior to this the Evans Stores building had been numbered variously 6-12 and 8-12...and as you point out, it's numbered 10-12 on the 1901 Rocks resumption plan...my source re the numbering 34-40 came via the above doc...which uses the contemporary street numbering...as you can see via Google Street view the Harbour Rocks Hotel actually sports the numbers 34-52...which also covers the adjoining terraces. So just to recap, the Evans Stores building was the building briefly used to house non-unionists during the 1890 maritime dispute...the Sydney Mail pic of the building matches up...but my comment re Ah Sing's grocery store and the 1919 soup kitchen is incorrect...they would have been located in the block up the street which you've noted as 34-40.
